# Use a changepoint set to break a time series into regions

Use a changepoint set to break a time series into regions

## Usage

``` r
cut_by_tau(x, tau)

split_by_tau(x, tau)
```

## Arguments

- x:

  A numeric vector

- tau:

  a numeric vector of changepoint indices

## Value

- `cut_by_tau()` a
  [`base::factor()`](https://rdrr.io/r/base/factor.html) of half-open
  intervals

&nbsp;

- `split_by_tau()` a named
  [`base::list()`](https://rdrr.io/r/base/list.html) of numeric vectors

## Details

A changepoint set `tau` of length \\k\\ breaks a time series of length
\\n\\ into \\k+1\\ non-empty regions. These non-empty regions can be
defined by half-open intervals, starting with 1 and ending with \\n+1\\.

`cut_by_tau()` splits a set of indices into a
[`base::factor()`](https://rdrr.io/r/base/factor.html) of half-open
intervals

`split_by_tau()` splits a time series into a named
[`base::list()`](https://rdrr.io/r/base/list.html) of numeric vectors

## See also

[`base::cut()`](https://rdrr.io/r/base/cut.html)

[`base::split()`](https://rdrr.io/r/base/split.html)

## Examples

``` r
n <- length(CET)

# Return a factor of intervals
cut_by_tau(1:n, tau = pad_tau(c(42, 81, 330), n))
#>   [1] [1,42)    [1,42)    [1,42)    [1,42)    [1,42)    [1,42)    [1,42)

# Return a list of observations
split_by_tau(DataCPSim, c(365, 826))
```
